questions.question: Question 1: Vascular injury causes intimal thickening by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.explanation:
Vascular injury results in intimal thickening due to smooth muscle proliferation. Vascular injury stimulates the migration of smooth muscle cells of the tunica media to the tunica 
intima. These smooth muscle cells proliferate and also synthesize extracellular matrix leading to 
intimal thickening. This is the stereotypical response of the vessel wall to an injury regardless of 
the cause of injury. The image below shows intimal thickening occurring in response to vascular injury. 631 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Endothelial dysfunction is implicated in all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Endothelial dysfunction is not implicated in aneurysm formation. An aneurysm occurs due to 
the pathology of connective tissue within the vascular wall. Endothelial dysfunction is the pathological alteration of the endothelium such that it 
becomes pro-inflammatory and prothrombogenic. It is caused by various injuries to endothelial 
cells: • Hemodynamic stresses - responsible for vascular pathology in hypertension • Lipid products - leading to the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis • Advanced glycation end-products (AGE) - responsible for diabetic microangiopathy • Viruses, bacterial products, cytokines, and complement components

The given image shows arteriosclerosis and calcification in the tunica media, that does not 
encroach on the vessel lumen. This is suggestive of Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. Monckeberg's medial sclerosis affects medium-sized muscular arteries and is characterized by 
calcification of the medial walls of the affected arteries. Adults aged over 50 years are usually 
affected. 632

patterns of arteriosclerosis: • Small vessel arteriosclerosis - involves small arteries and arterioles • It has two variants - hyaline arteriosclerosis, and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis • Monckeberg medial sclerosis - involves calcification of the walls of muscular arteries • Fibromuscular intimal hyperplasia- usually a healing response to inflammation (eg: arteritis) or 
mechanical injury (eg: stent insertion) • Atherosclerosis - mainly involves elastic and muscular arteries

questions.question:
Question 4: The following incidental finding is seen on a radiograph of a 60-year-old man. Which of the 
following is true regarding this condition?

options.a: It involves the internal elastic lamina
options.b: It involves the external elastic lamina

questions.explanation:
The given radiograph shows extensive calcification of the femoral arteries which is suggestive of 
Monckeberg medial sclerosis. It is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular 
arteries, typically starting along the internal elastic lamina and involves the media of the arteries. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is not associated 
with hypertension or diabetes. It is usually an incidental finding.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following pathological changes occurs in the small vessels of patients suffering 
from hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Hypertension results in hyaline arteriosclerosis of the small vessels. Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may 
lead to arteriosclerosis which is the thickening of the vessel wall. It has two variants which 
are hyaline arteriosclerosis and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. 633 
Sold by @itachibot In large and medium-sized arteries, hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the vessel 
walls, leading to: • Dissection • Aneurysm formation • Cerebrovascular hemorrhage • Acceleration of atherosclerosis

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is responsible for arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein 
deposition. Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein 
leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis 
by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline 
material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 65-year-old man presented with chest pain. Past history is significant for dyslipidemia and 
an ischemic stroke 2 years ago. Coronary angiography was performed and showed the 
following. What is the correct sequence of events leading to this condition?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery are 
suggestive of atherosclerosis. It progresses in the following sequence: • Endothelial injury and dysfunction • Accumulation of lipoproteins in the vessel wall • Monocyte adhesion to the endothelium • Platelet adhesion • Factor release from activated platelets, macrophages, and vascular wall cells • Smooth muscle cell proliferation, extracellular matrix production, and recruitment of T cells • Lipid accumulation both extracellularly and within cells • Calcification of ECM and necrotic debris late in the pathogenesis Hence, atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory and healing response of the arterial wall to 
endothelial injury. The two most important causes of endothelial injury leading to atherosclerosis 
are hemodynamic disturbances and hypercholesterolemia. The image below shows partial occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery. 637 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: What is the most important independent risk factor for atherosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
The most important independent risk factor for atherosclerosis is family history. The familial predisposition to atherosclerosis is usually polygenic. It is related to the familial 
clustering of other established risk factors, such as hypertension or diabetes. It may also be due to 
inherited variations in pathophysiologic processes such as inflammation. Hyperlipidemia (specifically hypercholesterolemia) is a major risk factor for atherosclerosis. Even 
in the absence of other risk factors, hypercholesterolemia is sufficient to initiate lesion 
development. 638 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is the most common site of atherosclerosis?
questions.explanation: The most common site of atherosclerosis is the lower abdominal aorta. In descending order, the most extensively involved vessels in atherosclerosis are: • Lower abdominal aorta • Coronary arteries • Popliteal arteries • Internal carotid arteries • Arteries of the circle of Willis

questions.question:
Question 12: The autopsy of a 14-year-old boy who died in a motor vehicle accident showed the following 
lesions on the inner surface of the aorta. What do these lesions indicate? 627 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows yellow spots on the inner surface of the aorta, which represent fatty 
streaks. They indicate a collection of foamy macrophages in the intima of the vessel wall. Fatty streaks may be present in the aorta of infants, virtually all adolescents, and even individuals 
without known risk factors. These lesions are not indicative of atherosclerosis, but some of 
them may evolve into atheromatous plaques later in life by smooth muscle proliferation and 
extracellular matrix deposition.

questions.question: Question 13: Where are the following cells in an atheromatous plaque derived from?
questions.explanation:
The cells marked in the image above are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques. They refer 
to lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques. These cells ingest lipoproteins accumulated within the intima of the vessel wall. Since these 
lipoproteins are modified due to the action of inflammatory mediators, they cannot be degraded 
further within these cells. This leads to the accumulation of modified lipids within these cells 
converting them to foam cells.

questions.question: Question 14: In which part of the atheromatous plaque are the T-cells and macrophages in abundance?
questions.explanation:
T-cells and macrophages are in abundance in the shoulder of an atheromatous plaque. Structure of an atherosclerotic plaque: • Superficial fibrous cap - made up of smooth muscle cells and connective tissue, especially 
collagen. It also contains macrophages, foam cells, and lymphocytes. It determines the stability of 
plaque. • Necrotic core - contains lipid (cholesterol and cholesterol esters), debris from dead cells, 
calcium, and foam cells. • Shoulder - a more cellular area containing macrophages, T-cells, and smooth muscle cells. 639 
Sold by @itachibot • Periphery - shows neovascularization/proliferation of small blood vessels. The image below shows the structure of an atherosclerotic plaque.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is true regarding a stable atherosclerotic plaque?
questions.explanation:
A stable atherosclerotic plaque has abundant smooth muscle cells. These cells synthesize collagen which stabilizes the plaque. Both these features contribute to a 
thick fibrous cap that prevents the easy rupture of a plaque. Stable plaque

questions.question:
Question 16: In a 50-year-old normotensive patient with a 10-year history of dyslipidemia, which of the 
following complications is he at the least risk of developing?
questions.explanation:
A 50-year-old patient suffering from dyslipidemia for the past 10 years is likely to have 
atherosclerosis. Dissection is associated with hypertension, not atherosclerosis. An atherosclerotic plaque may undergo pathological changes such as: • Thrombus formation - due to rupture, ulceration, erosion • Increase in plaque size - due to hemorrhage into the plaque These consequences occlude the lumen of the vessel and impair the blood supply. Impaired blood 
supply may lead to claudication, ischemic heart disease, myocardial infarction, cerebral infarction, 
or even gangrene. The thrombus may dislodge and cause an embolism. Atherosclerotic debris released due to plaque 
rupture may produce microemboli, known as atheroembolism. Atherosclerotic plaques also cause ischemic atrophy of the underlying media. This causes 
weakness of the vessel wall leading to aneurysm formation. The image below depicts the late complications of atherosclerosis. 641 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with anginal chest pain is planned for coronary angiography. What level of stenosis 
would you expect to see in the affected artery?
questions.explanation:
This symptomatic patient likely has >70% occlusion of his coronary arteries. This is known as 
critical stenosis. It refers to the stage at which the occlusion is sufficiently severe to produce tissue ischemia. This 
leads to clinical manifestations of ischemia such as: • Stable angina • Bowel ischemia • Intermittent claudication

questions.question: Question 18: Elevated levels of which of the following is not a predictor for stroke?
questions.explanation:
Elevated plasminogen levels are not associated with stroke. Elevated levels of the following are 
predictors for stroke: • C-reactive protein - also indicates risk for MI, PAD and used to monitor effectiveness of risk 
reduction measures like exercise, weight loss • Homocysteine - also correlates with MI, PAD, venous thrombosis, and premature vascular 
disease • Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 - marker of hemostatic and/or fibrinolytic function and also 
predicts risk of MI

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient presented with symptoms of heart failure. He had undergone a coronary bypass 
procedure with a small-diameter graft 3 weeks ago. What is the likely cause for his 
presentation?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of an early failure of a small diameter venous graft (8 mm). The 
likely mechanism for graft failure within the 1st month is acute thrombosis. Late vein graft failure (after months to years) is due to: • Neointimal hyperplasia (1 month to 1 year) • Atherosclerotic plaque (> 1 year) • Aneurysm Based on the diameter of the synthetic or autologous vascular graft, it can be: • Large diameter graft (12-18mm) - • Used in high-flow locations such as the aorta • Small diameter graft (8 mm) - • Includes saphenous vein or left internal mammary artery • Used in coronary bypass surgeries 642 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is false regarding the KLF-2 transcription factor?
questions.explanation:
Kruppel like factor-2 (KLF-2) is responsible for turning off the inflammatory gene transcription. KLF-2 production is induced by laminar blood flow which is seen in normal endothelium. This 
transcription factor activates the atheroprotective genes and turns off inflammatory gene 
transcription. Statins up-regulate KLF-2 expression in endothelial cells, and this activity is 
associated with an anti-inflammatory phenotype. Up-regulation of KLF-2 gene expression may be a novel strategy for the prevention and treatment 
of atherosclerosis. 643 
Sold by @itachibot Aneurysm and Dissection
